raw_text:
US woman sues over ink cartridges
 
 A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP), saying its printer ink cartridges are secretly programmed to expire on a certain date.
 
 The unnamed woman from Georgia says that a chip inside the cartridge tells the printer that it needs re-filling even when it does not. The lawsuit seeks to represent anyone in the US who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's biggest printer firm, declined to comment on the lawsuit. HP ink cartridges use a chip technology to sense when they are low on ink and advise the user to make a change.
 
 But the suit claims the chips also shut down the cartridges at a predetermined date regardless of whether they are empty. "The smart chip is dually engineered to prematurely register ink depletion and to render a cartridge unusable through the use of a built-in expiration date that is not revealed to the consumer," the suit said. The lawsuit is asking for restitution, damages and other compensation. The cost of printer cartridges has been a contentious issue in Europe for the last 18 months. The price of inkjet printers has come down to as little as £34 but it could cost up to £1,700 in running costs over an 18-month period due to cartridge, a study by Computeractive Magazine revealed last year. The inkjet printer market has been the subject of an investigation by the UK's Office of Fair Trading (OFT), which concluded in a 2002 report that retailers and manufacturers needed to make pricing more transparent for consumers.

The lawsuit seeks compensation and damages from HP customers since 2001.

tinyllama:1.1b: A US woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP) over ink cartridges, claiming the company programmed them with a chip that would expire on a fixed date even when they were not running low.

The lawsuit seeks compensation for anyone who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001 and alleges that the use of the chip to shut down cartridges and set their expiration dates constitutes false advertising and a deceptive trade practice.
The suit claims that the chip technology forces consumers to buy expensive replacement cartridges that do not last as long or offer better results than the original ones.

HP declined to comment on the suit, while the chip technology used in the cartridges is also claimed to have prematurely registered ink depletion and render them unusable beyond their expiration dates.
The suit is aimed at restitution, damage claims, and compensation for allegedly false advertising and deceptive trade practices related to printer cartridge usage.

The lawsuit seeks to represent people in the U.S. who have purchased HP inkjet printers since February 2001.

The suit claims that the chips used in HP ink cartridges prematurely register ink depletion and render a cartridge unusable through the use of a built-in expiration date that is not revealed to consumers.

The cost of printer cartridges has been a contentious issue in Europe for the last 18 months, with some retailers charging as much as £1,700 in running costs over an 18-month period due to cartridge prices.

granite3.1-dense:2b: A US woman, from Georgia, is suing Hewlett Packard (HP) for allegedly programming its ink cartridges with a built-in expiration date, even when the ink remains viable.
The plaintiff claims that a chip inside these cartridges falsely signals the printer to need refilling and eventually renders the cartridge unusable at a predetermined time, regardless of ink levels.

The lawsuit, which seeks restitution and damages for US consumers who purchased HP inkjet printers since February 2001, contends that this practice violates consumer rights by obscuring information about cartridge lifespan.

This issue has been a contentious point in European markets due to high running costs, with some estimates suggesting up to £1,700 in ink expenses over an 18-month period for an inkjet printer costing as little as £34.
The UK's Office of Fair Trading previously investigated and reported that retailers and manufacturers should improve pricing transparency for consumers.
